Her previous loan of 19,500 PHP (which she paid off well within its term) was just another step on her journey towards economic freedom. Delia hopes to improve her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is 37 years old. She is married has two children. She graduated from high school with a business degree. 

She owns a beauty salon and she needs this loan to develop her salon. Despite her small size of her shop, from its inception, she was able to attract many customers, especially brides, because she is a very good. She is so skilled at her craft that her income has risen and she has been able to hire a few women to help her. 

She has an excellent reputation in the market. Her location is so strategic that it falls in the busiest and richest part of town. Her style is so nice and mild that she has attracted more customers than other salons.

loans.use: To buy make-up and other supplies

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa S. is a 58-year old married woman who lives in Prk. Bolinao, Brgy Zone 2, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living through owning a general store.

Teresa’s husband, Marcos, helps her in running the business.  They have six children who are between 24-33 years old. With some of them already working, this has helped the family defray some of their expenses.

Teresa joined Kiva partner Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF)-Project Dungganon in 2006 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income through her general store. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 4,500 from her business activities.

Teresa is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 17,000 was used to fund the operations of her general store, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing for her 7th cycle loan an amount of Php 20,000 which she intends to use for her general store. Teresa is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the poverty alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To provide additional working capital.

loans.name: Pan

texts.en: Mr. Pan L., born in 1940, is married and blessed with five children, three of whom are now married and living separateL., while another two are single and employed in different occupations. Pan L. is engaged in his own business, the main operation of which is to build stone and wooden houses. As well, since the beginning of 1993 he and his wife have always taken time to raise rice and pigs for extra income. A hard-working man, Pan L. recentL. received an  order to build a new house, but he lacks the essential materials to perform his service. He is therefore requesting a loan of $600 to buy those materials.

loans.use: To buy essential materials to build a house for his customer

loans.name: Groupe 2

texts.fr:
Les huit membres du groupe 2 (de l’association Badenya de Zambougou Fouta) sont des femmes mariées dans des grandes familles traditionnelles avec en moyenne 40 ans et 4 enfants par femme. Elles habitent toutes dans le village de Zambougou Fouta dans la commune rurale de Tesserela dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de mariage. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs superficies culturales, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1er  cycle de prêt de campagne. 
Les membres du groupe vont cultiver l’arachide, le mil et le niébé.
Madame Maïmouna C. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter deux sacs de complexe céréale, 30kg de grains d’arachide, 5kg de grains de niébé et recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour et de récolte dans son champ d’arachide. Elle se ravitaille en intrants agricole à la foire de Gouassola et en main d’œuvre avec l’association des jeunes du village. 
Avec une superficie de 4 hectares elle espère produire 30 sacs d’arachide, 3 sacs de mil, 3 sacs de niébé et du fourrage. 
Les feuilles de niébé récoltées sont conçues en bottes, séchées et stockées. Elles sont revendues de même que la production du niébé et une partie de l’arachide pour gérer les petites dépenses du foyer au quotidien tandis que le reste d’arachide et le mil sont auto consommés en famille. 
Madame Maïmouna C. à l’instar des autres femmes du groupe 2 a pour objectif de faire l’élevage afin de se procurer  de matériels agricoles.
texts.en:
The eight members of Group 2 (of the Association of Badenya of Zambougou Fouta) are married women in large traditional families, who are on average 40 years old with four children. They all live in the village of Zambougou Fouta in the Tesserela commune of the Ségou region (the fourth administrative region of Mali), and met through family ties. In order to increase their cultivated areas, they have approached Soro Yiriwaso and are requesting their first loan. The group's members will grow peanuts, millet and black-eyed peas. Mrs. Maïmouna C. plans to use her loan to buy two bags of cereal fertilizer, 30 kg of peanut seeds, 5 kg of black-eyed pea seeds and to hire labourers who will work and harvest the crop in her peanut fields. She stocks up on her supplies at the Gouassola market and hires field hands through the village youth association. She has 4 hectares of land that she hopes will produce 30 bags of peanuts, 3 bags of millet, 3 bags of black-eyed peas, and some fodder. The leaves of the black-eyed peas are harvested, baled, dried and warehoused. These are then sold along with the black-eyed peas and a portion of the peanut harvest to provide for the day to day expenses of the household, while the rest of the peanuts and the millet will feed the family. Mrs. Maïmouna C., like the other women in Group 2, has a long term plan to raise animals in order to buy her agricultural supplies.

Translated from French by Eileen Jessop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cereal fertilizer, seed, and to pay for labour for field work and harvesting.

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta’s desire to give her children a brighter future fuels her commitment to her business. She is a very hard-working woman who is determined to achieve a better life.  Despite challenges and hardships caused by poverty, Violeta is dedicated to her mission of improving her family’s standard of living and she is supported by the love and care of her husband.

To earn a living, Violeta makes bamboo furniture and barbecue skewers. She has been engaged in this business for seven years. She joined ASHI, a microfinance institution and Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 2005,  During the course of her membership, she has been an excellent participant with respect to regular attendance at center and group meetings, loan repayment, and projects. She is now seeking her sixth loan, in the amount of 25,000 PHP,  to purchase raw materials needed to produce bamboo furniture (such as varnish, nails and bamboo shoots) and more stock for barbecue-skewer production.

With access to additional working funds through Kiva supporters, Violeta is optimistic that her dreams of sending her children to a university to complete college degrees will be achieved.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials needed to make bamboo furniture and barbecue skewers

loans.name: Elgen

texts.en:
Elgen B. is from the village of Bonbon Catarman   Camiguin. He is 44 years old  and widowed, with 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Elgen  provides taxi services to local community members. Elgen has been engaged in his business for more than 10 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Elgen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elgen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. That previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Elgen is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Elgen from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Groupe 3

texts.fr:
Le groupe 3 (de l’association Badenya de Zambougou Fouta) est composé de neuf femmes mariées dans des grandes familles traditionnelles qui ont en moyenne  41 ans, 3 enfants et habitent toutes dans le village de Zambougou Fouta dans la commune rurale de Tesserela dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de mariage. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs superficies culturales, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1er  cycle de prêt de campagne. 
Les membres du groupe vont cultiver l’arachide, le mil et le niébé.
Madame Fatoumata   Tata   C. qui est la présidente du groupe compte acheter avec son prêt deux sacs de complexe céréale, 50kg de grains d’arachide et recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour et de récolte dans son champ d’arachide. 
Elle se ravitaille en intrants agricoles à la foire de Gouassola et recrute des jeunes dans le village. 
Avec une superficie de 4 hectares, elle espère produire 25 sacs d’arachide, 5 sacs de mil, 4 sacs de niébé et du fourrage. Les fanes de niébé récoltées sont conçues en bottes, séchées et stockées. Elles sont revendues de même que la production du niébé et l’arachide pour gérer les petites dépenses du foyer au quotidien tandis que le mil est auto consommé en famille. 
Madame Fatoumata   Tata   C. à l’image des autres femmes du groupe 3 a pour objectif d’assurer l’auto suffisance alimentaire dans le village.
texts.en:
Group 3 (in the association of Badenya Zambougou Fouta) is composed of nine women married in traditional large families; on average they are 41 years old, have three children and they all live in the village of Zambougou Fouta in the rural community of Tesserela in the region of Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali). They got acquainted through ties of kinship and marriage. In order to increase their cultivated areas, they sought help from Soro Yiriwaso and are on their first cycle of farming loan. The group will grow groundnuts, millet and cowpeas. Ms. Fatoumata Tata C. who is the chairwoman of the group, plans to purchase two bags of cereal fertilizer, 50 kg of groundnut seeds and to recruit manpower for plowing and harvesting her groundnut field. She gets her agricultural inputs at the fair in Gouassola and recruits young people in the village. With an area of 4 hectares, she hopes to produce 25 bags of groundnuts, five bags of millet, 4 bags of cowpeas, and fodder. The cowpea vines are put in bales, dried and stored. They are sold as well as the production of cowpeas and groundnuts in order to pay for the small everyday household expenses while millet is self consumed in the family. Ms. Fatoumata C. Tata, like the other women in Group 3, aims to ensure food self-sufficiency in the village.

Translated from French by viviane reignier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing cereal fertilizer and seeds, and paying for manpower

loans.name: Angelica

texts.en:
Angelica B. is a 42-year old married woman who lives in Crossing Central Manapla, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures.  The first is food selling and the second is a sari sari (general) store.

Angelica’s husband, Noel, is a Timekeeper in a big plantation and they have two Children who are 8 and 15 years old. The two children go to school and also help their parents in the businesses as part of their daily chores.

Angelica joined Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF)- Project Dungganon in 1995 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in food selling and a sari sari store. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 8,000 from her business activities.

Angelica is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php20,000  was used to fund the operations of her general store and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing for her 13th loan in the amount of 20,000 which she intends to use on her sari sari (general) store and food selling. Angelica  is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the poverty alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To provide additional working capital.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Felipa

texts.en:
Felipa C. is from the village of  Camiguin Province. She is 41 years old. Felipa is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Felipa sells iced candy in the local community. Felipa has been engaged in her business for more than 3 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Felipa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Felipa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Felipa is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Felipa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Hom

texts.en: A widowed mother, Hom P., 46 years old, resides in the province of Siem Reap. Hom P. earns a living by raising pigs in a pigpen behind her house. She raises the pigs both for their offspring and for slaughter. In addition, she cultivates a rice crop. Hom P. has eight children who are all single. Two of her children are employees in a small firm. Hom P. is seeking a Kiva loan to purchase additional pigs to raise. This will provide her with greater profits.

loans.use: To buy more pigs to raise.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria  A. is a married woman who lives in Sitio Lag-it, Brgy. Okiot, Bais City, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating two businesses:  a general Store and a fishing business. Her husband Apolinario A., who is 60 years-old, works as a fisherman to earn his living and also helps with his wife's business activities.  They have one child who is 22 years-old. 

Victoria  joined Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF)-Project Dungganon in 1998 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 18 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Victoria  has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 9,000, thus, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 19th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,000 which she intends to use as additional capital for her sari sari store so that she can continue to save up for the future and to provide additional capital for her business. Victoria  A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the poverty alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To provide additional working capital.

loans.name: Badenya 4 Group

texts.fr:
Badenya 4 est un regroupement de dix femmes mariées majoritairement dans des grandes familles traditionnelles. Elles ont un âge moyen de 34 ans et 2 enfants. Elles habitent toutes le village de Zambougou Fouta dans la commune rurale de Tesserela dans la 4ème région administrative du Mali, qu’est Ségou. Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de mariage. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs superficies de culture, les membres du groupe ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1er  cycle de prêt de campagne. 
Elles font la culture d’arachide, du mil et du sésame.
Madame Adiara C. compte acheter avec son prêt 3 sacs de complexe céréale, 25kg de grains d’arachide et recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour et de sarclage dans son champ d’arachide. 
Elle se ravitaille en intrants agricoles à la foire de Gouassola et recrute des jeunes dans le village. 
Avec une superficie de 3 hectares, elle compte produire 28 sacs d’arachide, 3 sacs de mil, 6 sacs de sésame. 
Une partie de la récolte du mil et de l’arachide est auto consommée tandis que le reste est vendu. 
Le bénéfice obtenu est utilisé pour acheter des condiments dans les foires et assurer les soins de santé des membres du foyer. 
Madame Adiara C. à l’image des autres femmes de Badenya 4 a pour objectif d’assurer l’auto suffisance alimentaire dans le village.
texts.en:
Group 4 (of the association Badenya de Zambougou Fouta) is composed of six married women mostly in large traditional families.  The group members average 34 years of age and two children each, and they all live in the village of Zambougou Fouta, in the rural community of Tesserela (in Segou, the 4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They women know one another through ties of kinship and marriage. With the goal of expanding their arable land, the group members turned to the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their first farm loan cycle.  They grow peanuts, millet, and sesame.  Ms. Adiara C. plans to use her loan for buying three sacks of a fertilizer blend for grains and 25 kg of peanut seeds and for recruiting labor for plowing and seeding in the peanut field.  She gets her farm supplies at the Gouassola fair and recruits youngsters in the village.  With three hectares of land, she plans on producing 28 sacks of peanuts, 3 sacks of millet, and 6 sacks of sesame.  Part of the millet and peanut harvests will be consumed at home, while the rest will be sold.   The profits obtained will be used to buy some condiments at the fairs and to ensure the health care of members of the household.  Ms. Adiara C., like the other women of Group 4, has the goal of having enough food to be self-sufficient in the village. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fertilizer and seeds and to pay for workers

loans.name: Yoeurn

texts.en:
Yoeurn H. is a 44-year-old village woman who has had a job as a crop farmer since she was single. In addition, she currently sells fresh fish that she gets from her husband’s fishing or that she buys from her wholesale supplier and other fisherman. She runs her business in her community and earns approximately $4 a day.

Yoeurn H.’s husband is a local fisherman. The humble couple has six children, two of whom are married and the other four are single.

The coming rainfall is good for growing but Yoeurn H. doesn’t have capital yet to use on her farm. So she is looking for a loan to use towards purchasing fertilizers, insecticides, an irrigation pump, and corn seed so that she can begin planting.

loans.use: To use towards purchasing fertilizers, insecticides, an irrigation pump, and corn seed

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda B. is a 42-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating three business ventures: a general store, a videoke machine, and billiards (rent to play). She lives in  Brgy. Tamisu, Bais City, Negros Oriental. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2000 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard at her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now eans an average income of PHP 51,000. 

Luzviminda is now borrowing PHP 40,000 so that she can use it as additional capital for her general store and to purchase pigs for fattening. This will be her 16th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 30,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Luzviminda aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and to ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way. 

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Uranbileg

texts.en:
Uranbileg S. is 37 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Zavhan province in western Mongolia. She and her family live in a 'ger'- a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Her eldest child is a student, and the other two children attend a local middle school while her husband is a porter in Mah market and only earns seasonally. 

Uranbileg currently operates a small bakery in her town. She started a retail business in 2004. She makes a variety of breads and baked goods and has found success in her new venture and has increased her working capital which enabled her to purchase gifts such as a carpet and a TV set for her sister's wedding. She was able to cover her child's tuition fees and purchase 'ger' covering materials and a frying stove with her business earnings. 

Her daily sales reaches to 20-25 loaves of bread prepared with 8-10 kilos of flour. She is a hard-working, easy-going woman who is focused on the future growth of her business. She says, “ I have a plan to expand my business and to create a more efficient workplace in the future.” 

Uranbileg hopes to continue to grow her business in the future and is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more flour and other supplies and products for her business.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients to bake bread

loans.name: Eufronia

texts.en:
Eufronia is a 47-year-old mother of eight. She is a native of Talim Island from the town of Binangonan, which is located in Rizal Province in the Philippines. She is happily living with her 8 children and her 48-year-old husband, Virgilio, who is a bamboo set maker (furniture maker). 

Eufronia dreams of escaping the circle of poverty. She joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 2000 with hope of having access to capital to start a business. She and her husband are partners in their bamboo set making business. Since then her business has continued to grow and provide good income for her family but income from business in not enough to sustain everyday needs; therefore the couple now requests a much larger loan in the amount of 18,000 PHP for a bigger profits. The loan will be used to pay for inventory of raw materials of her business.

Eufronia is looking forward to increased demand for bamboo sets (furniture) on the island and in nearby towns so that their business will grow and generate enough income for her family. She dreams of sending her children to school until they finish college and find a stable living arrangement. She also hopes to build a new concrete, durable house for secure and comfortable living conditions.  Her long-term goal is to launch a new fishing business for additional income.

loans.use: To pay for raw materials for her bamboo set (furniture) making

loans.name: Minerva

texts.en:
Minerva M. is a 67-year-old widow who supports her family by owning and operating a general store. She lives in Prk. Bolinao, Manapla, Negros Occidental with her six children who are between 28 and 40 years old.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 2,000.

Minerva is now borrowing PHP 13,000 so that she can use it as additional working capital. This will be her 18th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 9,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Minerva aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Sun

texts.en:
Sun N. is a 46-year-old married woman and a local villager living in a medium-sized home with family members in a rural area of Siem Reap Province. She owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents. She uses this land to grow different kinds of crops. Sun N. has another financial earner in her husband who is a vehicle repairman. This couple has three school-aged kids, while another one is married and lives independently. 

To help alleviate her hard physical labor on the farm, Sun N. is taking out a loan to purchase a pair of cattle that she will use to plow the farmland.

loans.use: To purchase a pair of cattle to plow the farmland

loans.name: Bayarmaa

texts.en:
Bayarmaa Z. is 40 years old and lives with her husband and six children in Tosontsengel,  one of the biggest towns of Zavhan province, western Mongolia. She and her family live together in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Since 2000, Bayarmaa has run a special order home furnishings carpentry business with her husband.  Their workplace is located within their fence, where they live and operate their business. 

During the daytime, her husband, Bayaraa, makes wooden products such as upper frames, wooden walls, doors, and chests of drawers which are the parts and furniture of a 'ger'- a traditional housing tent, and they sell them to herdsmen. The couple has gained much experience in how to make wooden items well, according to their customers' demand and choice. The business income covers their family's needs and consumption. 

Bayarmaa says, “My dream is to purchase a plot of land for my family from my business profits. I wish my children would acquire a profession and I would see their future brighter than today.” Bayarmaa is a hard-working, modest woman who is struggling in life and anxious about her future. She is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 MNT in order to purchase raw materials and wood and timbers for her business.

loans.use: To purchase wood etc.

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer G. is a 29-year-old married woman who supports her family by owning and operating a general store and by selling rice. She lives in West Proper Talaban Zone 1, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental with her husband and their two children who are 3 and 7 years old.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and rice retailing business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 6,000.

Jennifer is now borrowing PHP 13,000 so that she can expand her general store and rice retailing business. This will be her 11th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Jennifer aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and to ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Buyanjargal

texts.en:
Buyanjargal B. is 38 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Tosontsengel, one of the biggest towns of Zavhan province, western Mongolia. She and her family live together in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Both of her children attend a local middle school while her husband helps her out with her business. 

She began her business in 2002 and now Buyanjargal operates a dairy product retail business in her town and drops the products off at a local market stall. She has been milking cows and producing dairy food since 2005. Besides that, she sells a variety of fruit during the peak months when prices for such products traditionally rise. 

Buyanjargal attributes her business success to her knowledge of local market demands.  She says, "Our family is in the process of building a new house near the local market and I wish I could own a small store over there. I am trying my best to operate my business well in order to increase my working capital and put money into my children's savings." She is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to purchase cows for her dairy production business.

loans.use: To purchase cows

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.en: Mary Grace A. is a married woman who lives in Hope Village, Brgy. Cabatangan, Talisay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a general store, selling fish and a tricycle transport business. Her husband, Jonathan, who is 35 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have four children who are 4 to 14 years old. Mary Grace joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she hoped for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Mary Grace has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 25,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of 6,000 PHP, thus improving the family's standard of living. This time, for her 14th loan, she is borrowing 28,000 PHP which she intends to use for her business so that she can continue to save up for her future and for the education of her children. Mary Grace A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Hun

texts.en:
Mrs. S. is a forty-eight-year-old clothing vendor residing in Battambang Province. She currently sells clothing for both men and women from her store in the local market. She is married with four children; one is already married and other three are single. Her husband is a military policeman. 

S. is an energetic woman who never wastes time as she works to earn the money to encourage all her kids to attain the highest levels of education. She has managed her investment carefully and has attracted a large number of customers due to her communication skills. 

S. has a son who is skilled at repairing mobile phones and he hopes to use his knowledge to earn money, but he doesn’t have money to use as capital. Therefore, S. has requested a loan of US$ 1,200 for her son to purchase repair material and essential tools to begin a phone mending service.

loans.use: To purchase any repair materials and tools

loans.name: Phou

texts.en:
Mrs. Phou C. T. is a middle-aged woman whose husband appears in the photo. She lives in the province of Battambang in Cambodia, where she earns a living raising pigs and crops. Since 2000, she has run this business and it has provided her with income to attain her present standard of living. She is married with five children who are secondary students. Her husband owns a motorcycle that he uses to provide a taxi service. 

In order to earn extra income, Phou C. T. will be using the loan to buy more pig-feed and piglets to raise.

loans.use: To buy more pig-feed and piglets to raise.

loans.name: Help Friends Group

texts.en:
Edward M., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called 'Help Friends'. He is 45 years old, single, and has two children who are 5 and 28 years old. He is a college graduate.

For 14 years, he has been selling drugs in a pharmacy in the Amaghashie Community, on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

He plans to use his 6,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more drugs for his pharmacy. He describes himself as friendly. His dream is to improve his business and be able to extend his pharmacy to a clinic.

loans.use: To buy more drugs for his pharmacy.

loans.name: We Are Not Alone Group

texts.en:
Mark L., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called 'We Are Not Alone'. He is 36 years old, single, and has two children,  4 and 7 years old. 

He is a college student and cares for two siblings. For 10 years, he has been selling tobacco in Redlight Market, on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

He plans to use his 8,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 36,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more tobacco. He describes himself as earnest.

His dream is to improve his business, build a house, and educate his children.  In the photo that accompanies this profile, Lawrence is inset at lower right because he was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more tobacco

loans.name: The Lord Is King Group

texts.en:
Boakai S., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called 'The Lord Is King'. He is 35 years old, married, and has two children, 3 and 6 years old. He was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to lack of support.
  
For 7 years, he has been selling rice in Redlight Market, on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

He plans to use his 6,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more bags of rice. His goal is to expand his business and educate his children.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 21-year-old single man living with his parents and 3 siblings. In 2007, he starts working in technology repairs, specialized in repairing computers, UPS, and  rechargeable mobile phones. He also works as a tattoo maker. He works in two jobs to make a good profit and provide a good life situation. Despite his young age, he has been able during 3 years to build up a good business reputation and good experience. 

He is requesting to borrow US$ 1000 to purchase a new tattoo machine to develop his business and attract more clients. And he plans in the future to open his own tattoo shop.

loans.use: purchase a new tattoo machine

loans.name: Mavjuda

texts.ru: Шерматова Мавчуда проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст, 40 лет. Замужем, имеет 4 детей. Образование среднее. Более 5 лет занимается торговлей на рынке. Она в основном продает фрукты. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en:
Mavjuda S. lives in the town of Kulob. Age: 40 years. Married, with four children. Education completed: secondary. She has been a vendor at the local market for over five years. She mostly sells fruits. She is taking out a loan in order to increase her stock level.

Translated from Russian by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing her stock level

loans.name: Neli Antonio

texts.pt:
Neli António T. vive em Boane, província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique. No empréstimo passado conseguiu comprar todo o material que esteve previsto e também foi suficiente. Também Conseguiu pagar a sua letra segundo o calendário estabelecido.
A sua obra está num estado bastante avançado, falta algumas coberturas e acabamentos. Na sua vida melhorou condição de habitabilidade. O presente empréstimo no valor de 17.000.00mt pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, pedra, areia, blocos e outros) para concluir a obra da sua casa. 
Esta muito satisfeito com o empréstimo, esta conseguindo reformar a sua residência. Pretende solicitar mais crédito para concluir a sua casa.
texts.en:
Neli António lives in Boane, in the Maputo Province, South of Mozambique. With her last loan she was able to buy all the materials needed and it has been enough to fulfill it. She was also able to pay her loan according to the established timeline. Her construction is in a very advanced stage, some roofing and finishings are missing. In her life, the living conditions have improved. The current loan, in the amount of 17.000.00mt, is intended to buy construction materials (cement, stones, sand, bricks and others) to finish the construction of her house. She is very pleased with the loan, she is managing to renovate her house. She intends to request more loans to finish her house.

Translated from Portuguese by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials (cement, stone, sand, bricks and others)

loans.name: Mother Blessing Group

texts.en:
Mark F., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called 'Mother Blessing'. He is 25 years old, married, and has one child who is three years old. He was only able to attend school through 8th grade due to lack of financial support.  

For 9 years, Mark has been selling soap, body crème, shampoo, hair grease and powder in Redlight Market outside of Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 9,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 36,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more soap, body crème, shampoo, hair grease and powder. He describes himself as kind and easy-going. His dream is to expand his business and build a house.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Nowah is inset at lower right because she was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more soap, body crème, shampoo, hair grease and powder

loans.name: We Praise God Group

texts.en:
J. F., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called 'We Praise God'. He is 77 years old, married, and has six children who range from 40 to 7 years old. He was not able to attend school due to poverty.  

For 20 years, he has been selling drinks (alcoholic beverages) in Redlight Market outside of Monrovia, Liberia.

He plans to use his 9,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 41,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more drinks (alcoholic beverages). He describes himself as peaceful. His dream is to improve his business and build a house.

loans.use: To buy more drinks (alcoholic beverages)

loans.name: Virginie

texts.en: Mrs. Virginie A. is 25 years old and works selling shoes in Lomé. She sells shoes at the Hedzranawoe Market, a large indoor market in the city. She is successful in this business and is now taking her third loan from WAGES in the amount of 300,000 CFA. She will use this to purchase more merchandise to sell at her shop in the market. With the increased profits she earns, Mrs. A. and her husband, also a merchant, will support their three children.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more rice, oil, beans and peppers

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is a 32-year-old married man who has three children in school. He runs a van transport business to earn a living.

David has managed to grow his business which has been running for four years and has two employees. He was previously selling shoes. He is married to a farmer and he works hard to provide for his family and also gives his wife support with the farming.

David joined a group in Faulu Kenya called “Prosper” whose members guarantee each other’s loans. He has requested a loan of Kes 80,000 to buy a vehicle engine. He hopes to own more vans for his transport business in the future.

loans.use: To buy a new engine for his vehicle

loans.name: Mouhamad

texts.en: Mouhamad, 36, is living in southern Lebanon. He is engaged and plans to get married soon. He has been working in agriculture since 1995. He plants all type of fruits and vegetables depending on the season. He plants watermelon, tomatoes, potatoes, lettuce, etc. Also, he has been managing his own olive oil production. Today, Mouhamad has requested his third loan: to prepare his land to be planted with rootstock. He has repaid his previous loans on time. His previous loans allowed him to improve his work and increase his income. His family depends on his income because it is additional revenue for them. For the future, he plans on getting married and wants to be able to provide the best to his future wife. He wants her to be very proud of him and does his best to improve his work in order to do so.

loans.use: To prepare his land to be planted with rootstock

loans.name: Fadi

texts.en:
Fadi is a 42-year-old borrower from Lebanon. He is married and has four children.

Fadi has been working in the business of stone-cladding since 1986. He has many years of experience and is proud of that. Over the years, he has built a good reputation in his region.

For the second time, Fadi has requested a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua. With his loan, he plans to purchase iron tools for his work. His previous loan allowed him to improve his work. His clients can be anyone from his region.

Fadi hopes, in the future, to keep on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase iron tools for his work

loans.name: Samia

texts.en:
Samia is a 33-year-old married woman from Lebanon who has two children. Since 2002, she has been working as a hairdresser and doing makeup. She also does hair removal and other beauty care. She notes that she is well known in her region, and that her clients feel comfortable coming to her because she is always aware of trendy fashions.

Today, for the second time, Samia has requested a loan from Al Majmoua to purchase tools needed for her business. Her previous loan allowed her to improve her work by always having the latest merchandise. In the future, she hopes to keep on improving and expanding her business.

loans.use: To purchase tools needed for her business

loans.name: Salim

texts.en:
Salim is a 47-year-old married man living in Lebanon with his wife and their two children. He works in construction and has many years of experience. He works on a freelance basis, taking housing projects and other projects such as building shops.

After gaining a good reputation in his occupation, Salim plans to expand his work. That is why, today, he has requested for the first time a loan to purchase tools for his work and to pay for his children’s school tuition fees. He hopes to keep on improving and expanding his work.

loans.use: To purchase tools for his work and to pay his children's school fees

loans.name: Emile

texts.en:
Emile is a 43-year-old married man living in Lebanon with his wife and their four children.

Emile owns a restaurant in his town where he serves all type of sandwiches like chicken, meat and more. He is well-known in his region for his tasty and delicious food.

Today, for the first time, Emile is requesting a loan to purchase tools and merchandise for his restaurant. His clients are his friends, neighbors and tourists. He says he is speciA. in his work because he knows how to treat his clients and is very welcoming.

Emile hopes to keep on improving his work.

loans.use: To purchase tools and merchandise for his restaurant

loans.name: United Women Group

texts.en:
Korto K., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called United Women. She is 40 years old, is married, and has five children who range from 1 to 24 years old. She was not able to attend school due to poverty.

For 20 years, Korto has been selling frozen fish and chicken in FDA Market, Paynesville, on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

Korto plans to use her 12,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 48,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more frozen fish and chicken. She describes herself as very hardworking.

Korto’s goal is to improve her business, build a shop, and educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more frozen fish and chicken to sell

loans.name: Abed El Aziz

texts.en:
Abed El Aziz is a 26-year-old single man living in Lebanon. Since 2004, he has been working in construction. This type of business is very common in Lebanon. 

Abed El Aziz is known for his good work and is proud of his experience. He is able to serve several clients at the same time. His clients are people from his region and its surroundings. 

He is requesting for the first time a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua. He plans to purchase a cement blender machine for his work. He hopes to continue to grow and enhance his business in the coming year.

loans.use: To purchase a cement blender machine

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more fish, chicken, meat, pepper, and onion

loans.name: Salim

texts.en:
Salim is a 54-year-old borrower from Lebanon. He is the father of two children. He has a chicken farm. His chickens are "layers" and he makes his living in egg production. 

Salim is requesting a loan in order to purchase chicks for his farm. This is the first time he has requested a loan. He hopes to continue improving his business in the coming year.

loans.use: To purchase chicks for his farm

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy two dairy cows

loans.name: Soubhiyeh

texts.en:
Soubhiyeh is a 56-year-old woman from Lebanon. Soubhiyeh decided to open a grocery store where she sells fruits and vegetables, as well as other groceries. In her grocery store, she offers bread, canned food, candies, beverages, and much more, to her clientele. She made this businees choice, because she wanted to supplement her family's income. 

When she first started, she had some financiA. issues and wasn't able to diversify her merchandise. Her clients are her friends, neighbors and tourists. 

Today, Soubhiyeh has requested a loan to purchase merchandise for her store. This is the first time she has requested a loan from A. Majmoua. She hopes that she will continue to improve her sales and, therefore, her income.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her store

loans.name: Riko

texts.en:
Riko P. is currently in the business of selling bread and groundnut paste at the market and is requesting a loan to stock tomatoes to sell. Riko is 43 years old and married to a soldier. She has three children and her children go to school.  

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a motorbike for her children to be used as a means of transport to school.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. 

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Jihad

texts.en:
Jihad is a 41-year-old man from Lebanon. Jihad is married and the father of six children. Jihad is a farmer. His main interest is in raising different types of livestock, especially goats, sheep, and cows. Since 2000, he runs his own farm. He is proud of this. His customers include people from his region and its surroundings. He notes that when he first started his business, he had some difficulties in starting up, but he prevailed.

Today, for the first time, he has requested a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua. He plans to purchase a cow with this loan. For the future, he plans to keep on improving his work and is confident that his loan will allow him to grow his business.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Abdallajh

texts.en:
Abdallah is a 39-year-old borrower from Lebanon. He has four children. He has been working in the field of agriculture since 1995. He owns livestock, specifically sheep and goats. He raises livestock and sells milk. 

Today, for the first time, Abdallah has requested a loan. He hopes to purchase a sheep. When he first started, he had difficulty starting up his business, but his efforts paid off. His clients are people from his region and its surroundings. For the future, he plans to expand his livestock and therefore improve his income.

loans.use: To purchase a sheep

loans.name: Nazih

texts.en:
Nazih, age 41, is a borrower from Lebanon. He is the father of three children. He has been working as a blacksmith since 2000. He is skilled at many kinds of metalwork including the making of furniture. Nazih is proud of his experience and strong reputation, but he notes that it has been a challenge to secure financing for his business. 

Today, for the first time, Nazih is requesting a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua in order to purchase an iron-cutting machine. In the future, he hopes to continue improving and expanding his work.

loans.use: To purchase an iron-cutting machine

loans.name: Tereza

texts.en:
Tereza N., age 29, is a fruit seller. Her wares are such fruits as bananas, mangoes, pineapples, and jackfruits. She would like to expand her selection and  is requesting a loan in order to stock dried fish to sell. Tereza's husband is a police officer and they have one child. With the profits from her loan, she hopes eventually to be able to build a house to offer for rent as an additional source of income.

About BRAC:

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights services, and legal services, all of which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is paticularly targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock dried fish to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more water and juice

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
Charity S. is currently in the business of selling bags of charcoal from her home. She  is requesting a loan in order to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Charity is 37 years old and is married. Her husband is a soldier. She has three children, all of whom attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build her own shop.

About BRAC:

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights services, and legal services, all of which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is paticularly targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 48-year-old single woman who lives alone. She runs a tailoring business from her home. She has been involved in this occupation since 2000 and offers all types of tailoring and sewing services to her customers. She works hard to meet her living expenses. 

This is her second loan, and she tells us that she found that the first loan amount was appropriate given her business needs and repayment ability. Over the course of her loan term, she consistently paid on time, and she even repaid the full loan amount earlier than her scheduled end date.  

Today, she is hoping to borrow $1,500 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. in order to purchase much-needed tailoring supplies. In the future, she would like to expand her client base, and she hopes eventually to open a small tailoring factory.

loans.use: To purchase essential tailoring supplies

loans.name: Oliver Del Carmen

texts.es:
Oliver del Carmen  de 39 años, vive en la Primavera de Duran (zona periurbana, con una ecología en disolución), ella tiene una tienda de pañales desde que se separo de su esposa el se tuvo que hacer cargo de sus dos hijos.

Por la falta de oportunidades y la idea de mantener a sus hijos con ella, tuvo invertir sus ahorros en pañales para venderlos a sus conocidos, poco a poco con esfuerzo y dedicación tuvo dinero para invertir más, ahora el trabaja con su hija mayor de 18 años en la venta de pañales,  cada paquete de pañal lo vende a $ 9.00. 

Para continuar con su negocio ella quiere comprar con el préstamo una vitrina y pañales para su negocio, en el futuro quiere ampliar su negocio con otros artículos.
texts.en:
Oliver del Carmen is 39 years old and lives in Primavera de Duran (a periurban area with a deteriorating ecosystem). After she separated from her husband, she opened a store where she sells diapers because she had to take care of her two children.

Since opportunities were lacking and she needed to support her children, Oliver del Carmen invested her savings in diapers and sold them to acquaintances. Through her effort and dedication, she gradually earned more money to invest into her business. She now works with her oldest daughter, who is 18, selling diapers. Each packet of diapers sells for $9.00.

In order to continue her business, Oliver del Carmen will use her loan to buy a display cabinet and more diapers. In the future, she wants to expand her business by offering other products.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase diapers & a display cabinet

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
This is Mary M., age 44, who is currently in the business of selling maize flour and rice at her local market. She is requesting a loan in order to stock beans and pulses to sell. Mary and her husband have four children, all of whom attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up her own shop.

About BRAC:

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights services, and legal services, all of which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is paticularly targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock beans and pulses to sell

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael, age 37, is the father of three children. He operates a "Bodaboda," which is a motorbike transport business. He is also a mixed agricultural and dairy farmer: he grows a tea crop as well as engaging in dairy farming. 

He joined the Kamburu Pamoja group in order to access financial resources from Faulu Kenya. In a group loan such as this, the members guarantee each other's loans. Michael has previously taken out a loan in the amount of Kes. 20,000, which he used to buy a dairy cow. This loan was successfully repaid. 

He is now requesting a loan in the amount of Kes. 50,000 in order to buy a Heifer. Michael hopes to open his own hardware shop in the future.

loans.use: To buy a Heifer

loans.name: Ludy

texts.en: Ludy R. is a 43-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures: a sari sari (general store) and a fish vending business. She lives in Sitio Canibol, Brgy. Okiot, Bais City, Negros Oriental. Ludy has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1998 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her sari sari store and fish vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average income of 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). Ludy is borrowing 19,000 PHP as additional capital for her sari sari store. This will be her 19th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 19,000 PHP ( which she paid off well within its term) was just another step on her journey towards economic freedom. Ludy hopes to improve her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Zelaeh Group

texts.en:
Kebbeh Z., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Zeleah. She is 43 years old, married and has four children who range from 16 to 25 years old. She was not able to attend school due to lack of financial support. 

For five years, she has been selling rice and oil in Redlight Market, Paynesville, on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more bags of rice and oil. She describes herself as respectful. 

Her goal is to expand her business, build a house, and continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice and oil

loans.name: Dwaaho Ladies Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Mary describes herself as a hard-working woman. She is 54 years old and she is the leader of the “Dwaaho” Ladies borrowing group. Dwaaho is the name of their community. Mary is a petty trader who has been selling foodstuffs for the past 8 years. She is excited to be taking the loan, which she plans to invest in the purchase of bags of maize. She dreams of being able to travel outside her town to procure maize in bulk to serve her customers.  She is married to a mechanic and together they have three children, ages 15, 22 and 26 years. Mary hopes to mobilize more savings to support her children to attain quality education. 

The other members of her group are traders who sell foodstuffs, etc. Mary believes she was chosen as leader because of her good organizing ability. As the leader of the group, she ensures regular meeting attendance and repayment of loan installments.

loans.use: To purchase maize in bulk

loans.name: Loice

texts.en:
Loice K., age 29, sells green vegetables at her local market. She is requesting a loan because she would like expand her offerings to include dried fish. With this loan, she will be able to stock an inventory of dried fish to sell. Loice and her husband, who works as a driver, have one child. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up her own shop.

About BRAC:

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights services, and legal services, all of which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is paticularly targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock dried fish to sell

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose J., age 39, is a vendor of fried and roasted cassava tubers and potatoes. She is requesting a loan in order to stock carrots to sell. Rose's husband, who is a police officer, have three children. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes eventually to be able to open up her own restaurant.

About BRAC:

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights services, and legal services, all of which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is paticularly targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock carrots to sell

loans.name: One Love Group

texts.en:
Nancy S., shown holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers. The group is called One Love. Nancy is 35 years old and married. She was not able to attend school due to lack of financial support. For the last five years, she has been a vendor of rice and meat at Redlight Market in Paynesville, located on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 8,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 40,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more bags of rice and meat. She describes herself as a determined woman.

Her goal is to expand her business and eventually to build a shop.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice and meat for sale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of rice and gallons of oil

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 42-year-old married woman. As the mother of three school-age children, she decided to build up a tailoring business in her home. She takes on tailoring work upon client request and produces a variety of new clothes in addition to offering clothing repair services. With her home business income, she has been able to help her husband in supporting the household. She and her husband share the goal of supporting their children in completing their education through the university level. 

Today, she is requesting $700 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. in order to improve her business. She also wants to purchase textiles so she can offer a variety of products to her customers and increase her sales.

loans.use: To improve her business and to purchase textiles

loans.name: Ignacia

texts.en: Ignacia K. is a married woman who lives in Sitio San Jose, Brgy. II, Bais City, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a sari sari (general store) and a food vending business. Her husband, Alfredo K., age 57, works as a tricycle driver to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have six children who are 13 to 33 years old. Ignacia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 because she hoped for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Ignacia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 20,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of 16,800 PHP, thus improving the family's standard of living. This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing 20,500 PHP which she intends to use to purchase piglets and as additional capital for her main business so that she can continue to save up for the future and for the education of her children. Ignacia K. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary is 40 years old and has been a farmer for three years. She grows coffee and also engages in dairy farming. Rosemary supplies milk to the Fresha Processing Milk Company. 

She is a member of Ikinu Aimers in Faulu Kenya, where she saves her money. Through this group, she was previously guaranteed a loan of 20,000 KES. She utilized this loan to buy a dairy cow. She is now requesting a loan of 35,000 KES in order to buy a dairy cow and to renovate the cow shed.  She hopes to educate her son to university level. As a single mother, she works hard to provide for her son. In ten years, she hopes to become a large-scale farmer.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow and renovate the cow shed

loans.name: Amen Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Petty trading like the sale of cosmetics is widespread in Ghana because it is easy to start. A large number of women wear make-up and use one cosmetic product or another to add beauty to their appearance. Different occasions define which make-up is appropriate for most of the women, making the sale of cosmetics a lucrative job for many women. 

Yaa is one of such entrepreneurs who have been selling cosmetics for the past ten years. She currently sells on a table top in the market, hoping that, one day, she will be able to grow her business into a cosmetics wholesale shop. She is excited to be taking the loan which she plans to invest in purchasing assorted cosmetics in bulk to serve her customers. She anticipates increasing her profit level and also expanding her market.

Apart from being an entrepreneur, Yaa also provides support to her thirteen-year-old child in school, hoping that he will be able to enter university. Currently, Yaa is the group leader of “Amen” Trust Bank Group made up six members. The other members are mainly food traders and food processors.

loans.use: To purchase assorted cosmetics in bulk

loans.name: Luciana

texts.en:
Luciana V. is a 56-year-old maried woman who supports her family by engaging in three businesses: a general store, water refilling, and electronic reloading. She lives in Brgy. Dapitan Cordova, Cebu City with her 60-year-old husband, David, who works as a tricycle driver and their 32-year-old child who has a family.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since June of 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000.

Luciana is now borrowing PHP 29,500 so that she can expand her general store, water refilling and electronic reloading businesses. This will be her 12th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 25,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Luciana aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Bernardita

texts.en:
Bernardita L. is a 55-year-old married woman who lives in Prk. Tulay, Brgy Day-as, Corcova, Cebu City. She earns a living by owning and operating a general store, videoke machine, and computer games business.

Bernardita’s husband, Sergio, is a 58-year-old jeepney driver, and they have four children who are between 18 and 33 years old. One child is currently going to school and also helps Bernardita and Sergio in the business as part of daily chores. Two other children are already working. The fourth has a family.

Bernardita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 hoping that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of their family's life. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in these businesses. Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP 6,000 from her business activities.

Bernardita is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 was used to fund operations of her general store, and it had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing for her 13th cycle loan, the amount of PHP 14,000, which she intends to use on her general store, videoke machine and computer games business. Bernardita is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:

Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital for businesses

loans.name: Consolacion

texts.en:
Consolacion V. is a 41-year-old married woman who lives in Brgy. Kabangbang, Bantayan, Cebu City. She earns her living by selling bags and footwear.

Consolacion’s 45-year-old husband, Jumar, helps her in running the business. They have four children who are between 16 and 22 years old. The children are currently going to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores.

Consolacion joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 hoping that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of their family's life. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income through her business. Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP 36,000 from her business activities.

Consolacion is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500 was used to fund operations of her business selling ready-to-wear clothes and footwear. It had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing for her 22nd cycle loan, the amount of PHP 29,500, which she intends to use on her business selling bags and footwear. Consolacion is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary, 49 years old, is married and has three children. She has been selling vegetables for six years to earn a living. She also engages is cattle farming, an endeavor in which she rears dairy cows and pigs in order to supplement her family’s income. She joined Tingonga Vision Group with the aim of saving money and being guaranteed a loan from Faulu Kenya. She has requested a loan in the amount of 30,000 KES so that she can buy a dairy cow.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Jeniffer

texts.en: Jeniffer B. is a 33-year-old married woman who supports her family by selling nipa leaves and water refills. She lives in Prk. Orchids, Brgy. Enclaro Vista Aligre, Ilog, Negros Occidental with her husband, Alex, a 39-year-old tricycle driver, and their four children who are between 3 months and 12 years old. Jeniffer has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard buying and selling nipa leaves and in her water refill business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 20,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). Jeniffer is borrowing 27,000 PHP to use for her businesses. This will be her tenth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 25,000 PHP (which she paid off well within its term) was just another step on her journey towards economic freedom. Jeniffer hopes to improve her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Susan

texts.es: Susan, de 29 años de edad, convive con su pareja. Juntos residen en la localidad de Quimbiri, ubicada en la hermosa selva cusqueña, donde tienen su propia casa. Susan es de las personas a las que les gusta hacer las cosas en equipo, es por ello que junto con su pareja decidieron abrir un negocio de venta de bebidas en general. En un inicio tuvieron problemas económicos, pero poco a poco lograron recuperarse. Actualmente el negocio que posee lo ha complementado con la venta de comida, típica de la selva. De esta manera sus ganancias han aumentado. Su punto de venta lo realiza cerca de la estación de policía, desde las 7:00 de la mañana hasta las 10:00 de la noche.
