loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Narmandah

texts.en:
Narmandah L. is 46 years old and lives with her husband and son in Uvurhangai province in central Mongolia. Her son is a student in a university, while her husband is retired but helps with her business. 

Narmandah operates a consumer goods and clothing mobile business in her town. She purchases and imports her products in Ereen, a border city of China. By managing and conducting her business successfully, she has been able to achieve stable operations in a short time. 

Her husband Dashzeveg is a very talented person who makes horse-head fiddles and trains children as fiddle players. He has used the success of his business to greatly improve his quality of life and has made at least 50 to 60 horse-head fiddles. For the future, the couple hope to improve the quality of the musical instrument and their business earnings. 

Narmandah hopes her business profit will enable her to pay her son's university tuition fee. She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to buy more clothes and consumer goods in Ereen, China.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and consumer goods to sell

loans.name: Thoa

texts.en:
Thoa T. L. was born in 1966. She not only grows rice but  she also raises pigs and poultry. Now, she is raising 400 chickens and 10 pigs. She lives with her husband and three children (two sons and one daughter). But her eldest son has a disability. 

Her husband is a farmer; they work together. They have a monthly income of about 4,000,000 Vietnamdong (VND). This is the first time she is participating in SEDA. She would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND to buy feed for her pigs and poultry.

loans.use: to buy feed for pigs and poultry.

loans.name: Altantsetseg

texts.en:
Altantsetseg T. is 49 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in Uvurhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family all live together in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her daughter is a student while her husband works as a director of Uvurhangai province Democratic Party Branch. 

Altantsetseg operates a small cafe in her town with the help of her family. She started her cafe in 2005 out of a small rented place next to her house. Due to her hard work, she has found success in a short time and built a two-storey house in where she is currently operating her cafeteria business. For the future, Altantsetseg hopes to expand her business so she can better serve all of her customers. She is a hard-working, productive woman who is requesting a 4,000,000 MNT loan in order to buy more materials, kitchen implements and equipment, and food ingredients in order to cook satisfying meals for her customers.

loans.use: To purchase equipment and inventory

loans.name: Gai

texts.en: Gai T. T. was born in 1971. She has a carpentry workshop. She has three children (two sons and one daughter). Her husband is a carpenter. Mrs. Gai and her husband work together. They produce furniture out of wood (beds, tables, etc.). They have a monthly income of about 5,000,000 Vietnamdong (VND). This is the first time Mrs Gai is participating in SEDA. She would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND to buy wood.

loans.use: to buy wood

loans.name: Batjargal

texts.en:
Batjargal L. is 47 years old and lives with her husband and children in Uvurhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family live together in a 'ger'--a traditional housing tent. Her elder son is a student, while the two daughters attend a local middle school. 

Batjargal operates a food selling business out of her own small space at the local market. In 2004 she began her consumer goods retailing business and over the years she has worked hard to build a stable business operation and has gained much experience. 

During the summertime, she sells a variety of dairy products and ice-cream. Her business is very important to her and her family. She says, "I really want to expand my business in order to improve my quality of life and am trying my best to achieve that goal. Plus, my only wish is to provide a good education for my children and to help them become good people." 

Batjargal is a modest and very hard-working woman. She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more dairy products to sell in the business.

loans.use: To purchase more dairy products to sell

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda M. is from the village of  Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 54 years old. Rosalinda is married and has 6 children. To make a living, Rosalinda owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Rosalinda has been engaged in her business for over 3 years.

In 2010, Rosalinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalinda is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Rosalinda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nhan

texts.en:
Nhan T. N. was born in 1977 and lives in Khu5 village. She has three children (two sons and one daughter).

Nhan T. N. and her husband sell building materials. They have a truck and her husband is a truck driver. They have a monthly income of about 6,000,000 Vietnamdong (VND).

This is the first time Nhan T. N. has participated in SEDA. She would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND to expand her building materials shop.

loans.use: To expand her building materials shop

loans.name: Chimgee

texts.en:
Chimgee S. lives with her two children in Uvurhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her children live together in a house. Her elder daughter attends a local middle school while her husband works in South Korea.

Chimgee operates a small cafe in her town. She began her business in 2009 as a food retailer. After years of successful business, she planned to operate a fast-food service to her customers at local businesses and at the market. Her cafe specializes in a variety of meals.

Chimgee is now thinking about expanding her business. She hopes to increase her working capital and open a bigger and popular fast-food center in her town. Chimgee is requesting a 3,100,000 MNT loan to purchase kitchen equipment, tools and supplies to start her new venture.

loans.use: To purchase kitchen equipment, tools and supplies

loans.name: Macaria

texts.en: Macaria L. is from the village of Santiago, Misamis Oriental. She is 52 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Macaria owns and operates a business providing waste management services, primarily buying and selling plastics and other recyclables for local businesses and community members. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Macaria joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional plastics and other recyclables to sell. Macaria is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional plastics and other recyclables to sell. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional plastics and other recyclables to sell

location.town: Santiago, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Abida Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Abida perveen is the wife of S. A. who has a bangles shop in the market. They live in a city called Vehari, Pakistan, and have four children, all of whom are getting their education.

Abida also sells bangles by visiting different areas of the town. Her income is good but she is facing problems of low stock these days.

Abida is applying for a loan to buy more bangles for her business. In this way she will not only increase her income but she will also be able to put aside some stock for later use.

In the photo, Shagufta, a group member, is showing clothes from her clothes business.

loans.use: To purchase more bangles to sell

loans.name: Pol

texts.en:
Mrs. Pol M., 53, supports her family by selling fish paste in a small market located in her village. She either gets the fresh fish from her husband’s fishing or buys them from other fishermen. Then she turns the fresh fish into fish paste to sell for a profit. She is able make a least $2 a day to solve the financial problems of her family.

Pol M. is married with five children: two are married and live independently while three are single and live at home. Her husband fishes in the river to earn a living.

In addition, the family always takes time to farm a rice crop for the dual purpose of eating and selling. It is an annual business this couple has done with great success for a long time.

The heavy rainfall is starting which is good for growing, but Pol M. doesn’t have capital yet to use on her farm. So, she is looking for a loan to use towards planting her rice crop.

loans.use: To use towards planting her rice crop

loans.name: Anh

texts.en:
Anh T. K. D. was born in 1975. She lives in Khu5 village and is married with one child. Her husband is a carpenter.  

Anh T. K. D. has a small shop which makes wood items such as doors and furniture including beds and tables.  The family monthly income is about 5,000,000 Vietnamdong (VND). This is the first time she is participating with Kiva partner SEDA. She would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND to expand her shop.

loans.use: To expand her shop.

loans.name: Divine

texts.en:
Divine E. is from the village of Santiago, Iligan City. She is 34 years-old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Divine owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling food and daily use products in the local community. Divine has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Divine joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Divine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Divine is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Divine from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

location.town: Santiago, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Vorn

texts.en: Vorn N. is a 53-year-old woman and a local villager living in a medium-sized home with family members in Kompong Tom Province. She owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents who died of senility. She uses this land to raise crops and a few pigs. Vorn N. is a  mother blessed with five children. Two of them are already married and live away from home, while the remaining three are unmarried. Almost all of the children are employed. As another source of family income, Vorn N.’s husband sells firewood that he buys from the forest. To help alleviate the hard physical labor of the business activities, Vorn N. is seeking a loan to purchase a pair of water buffalo that she will use to plow the farmland and carry the firewood from the forest.

loans.use: To purchase a pair of water buffalo.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda is 46 years old and married with three children. She lives with her family in the province of Rizal in the Philippines.

To supply additional income for her family, Yolanda is starting a hog-fattening business. She is motivated and determined to launch a successful business endeavor of her own.

Yolanda would like to receive a loan to purchase feeds and vitamins for her hogs. As a member of Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva micro-finance partner in the Philippines, Yolanda is thankful for access to capital and loans to support her entrepreneurial dreams.

Yolanda’s longterm goals are to build a sustainable business, to fund her children’s college education, and for her family to have their own car. With the support of Kiva lenders, Yolanda is positive that her business will generate sound profits to improve her financial stability and her family’s quality of living.

loans.use: To purchase feeds and vitamins for her hogs

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice A. is from the village of Bagong Silang, Iligan City. She is 29 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Alice owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling electronic products like DVD players and also DVDs and VCDs in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Alice joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. Alice is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

location.town: Bagong Silang, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Sandra Rafael

texts.pt:
Sandra Rafael M., nasceu no Distrito de Namaacha Província de Maputo Sul de Moçambique, vive maritalmente é mãe de uma filha de 21 anos que vai a escola.fez a 9ªclasse, parou com os estudos quando foi ao lar. Vive na casa própria com a sua neta e sustenta dois enteados que vivem com ela.

Sandra quando junta se com seu marido, aranja um emprego no Centro de Saúde de Namaacha como Servente onde trabalha das 7:30h sa 15:30h auferindo mensalmente 2.200.00mt que aplica nas dispesas da casa. Mas devido ao facto do seu entiado ser o herdeiro da casa onde se encontram, ela legaliza um terreno em nome da   filha e pede empréstimo a Hluvuku e Kiva para dar inicio da construção de uma moradia que sera construida pelo marido que é pedreiro.



Este é o primeiro empréstimo de Sandra na Hluvuku e Kiva no valor de 10.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção ( pedras locais, cimento, areia) e dar inicio da construção de uma casa para a filha. Esta confiante que vai pagar antes do tempo pois conta com ajuda do seu marido que é pedreiro. Tem maior sonho de se casar oficialmente e ter uma vida condigna.
texts.en:
Sandra Rafael was born in the district of Namaacha in the province of Maputo, South of Mozambique. She is in a common law marriage and is the mother of a 21 year old daughter who goes to school. She studied through 9th grade and stopped when she moved in with her husband. She lives in her own home with her granddaughter and supports two stepchildren who live with her. When she moved in with her husband she found a job a the Namaacha Health Center as a janitor where she works from 7:30am to 3:30pm and makes 2,200 meticais per month which goes to house expenses. Due to the fact that her stepson will inherit the house they live in, she is registering a lot of land in her daughter's name. She is requesting Hluvuku and Kiva for a loan to start building a house there. Her husband, who is a bricklayer, will build the house. This is Sandra's first loan with Hluvuku and Kiva and it is for 10,000 meticais. She intends to use it purchase construction materials (local stone, cement, sand) and start building a house for her daughter. She is confident she will pay back the loan ahead of time since she will have help from her husband who is a bricklayer. Her biggest dream is to be legally married and to have a suitable life.

Translated from Portuguese by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials (local stones, cement, sand)

loans.name: Maryam Bibi's Group

texts.en:
Maryam bibi lives with her family in a a mid-sized city called Vehari in Pakistan. She is the mother of four children who are all working. Her husband has a business selling gas cylinders and has of seven years of experience in this business. Maryam is a housewife who takes care of her family by staying at home.

Maryam is applying for a loan from Asasah to invest in her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will expand his gas cylinder business by buying more cylinders of LPG (Liquid Petroleum Gas) gas. He hopes that this will increase his sales especially as he earns a good profit on each cylinder.

In the photo, Latifan, another group member, is demonstrating her shoemaking business.

loans.use: To enable her husband to purchase more LPG cylinders for his business

loans.name: Renelda

texts.en: Renelda T. is from the village of Bagong Silang, Iligan City. She is 39 years old, is married and has five school-aged children. Renelda owns and operates a business selling lumber. She is just starting this business. In 2009, Renelda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. Renelda is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

location.town: Santiago, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Po

texts.en:
Mr. Po L. is a middle-aged man whose wife is shown in the photo. She stays at home to take care of three small kids. She also raises pig and crops for a profit.

Po L. travels to the forest, where he cuts a pieces of chop-wood (firewood). He hurries to bring the chop-wood back to his house and sell it to people who need it as fuel to cook their food. By doing this, he is able to earn $6 each day to support his famiL.’s daiL. expenses.

Po L. faces a problem: his existing cart has frequentL. broken down when he uses it to pick up his firewood and it has been affecting his income. In order to help solve this problem, he has asked for a $700 loan in order to replace his broken cart.

loans.use: To replace his broken cart

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna D. is from the village of Bagong Silang, Iligan City. She is 53 years old, widowed and has 4 adult-aged children. Edna owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Edna has been engaged in her business for over 35 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Edna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Edna is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Edna from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital

location.town: Bagong Silang, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Eden

texts.en:
Eden V. is from the village of Molave. She is 45 years old and married with five school-aged children. Eden owns and operates a farming business, planting and selling her own-harvested rice in the local community. Eden has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Eden joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eden is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional stock to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Eden from PMPC. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: additional stock for her sari- sari store

loans.name: Medy

texts.en:
Medy S. is from the village of Guinabot. She is 32 years old, married and has school-aged children. Medy has been selling household items in the local community for the past 5 years. Through this activity, she is able to earn a monthly net income of 2,600 PHP. In 2009, Medy joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Medy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC, which was used as additional capital for her business. Medy is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used for the expansion of her business. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Medy from PMPC.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For the expansion of her business

loans.name: Adriano

texts.pt:
Adriano S. nasceu na Provincia de Gaza, Sul de Moçambique, é casado pai de 7 filhos de 18,20,22,26,28,30 e 32 anos três mais novos é que vão a escola. Vive na casa própria com sua familia, responsabiliza se pelos seus dois netos que vivem com ele.


Adriano sai de Gaza para Maputo aprocura de emprego, apos sua chegada começa a trabalhar como empregado doméstico e estudava de noite,hoje é docente já reformado a mais de 8 anos recebendo 3.034.36mt mensalmente. Para alêm da reforma, trabalha na quinta como jardinheiro auferindo 1.800.00mt por mês. Também é criador de pintos, proprietário de uma capoeira onde cria em média 3 caixas alternadamente gastando 20.000.00mt e tendo de lucro 9.000,00mt caso não haja muito frio, o mesmo aplica nas despesas de casa e consegue poupar algum na sua conta bancaria.   

Já teve empréstimo no BIM no valor de 30.000.mt que esta quase a findar. Este é o primeiro empréstimo de Adriano na Hluvuku e Kiva no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar pintos de criação para revenda. Esta confiante que vai reembolsar antes do tempo, e na base deste empréstimo, analizar se vale a pena criar com empréstimo para poder aceder a outros.
texts.en:
Adriano Hortencia was born in the Province of Gaza, South of Mozambique. He is married and father to 7 children who are 18, 20, 22, 26, 28, 30 and 33. The three youngest are the ones who go to school. He lives in his own home with his family. He also supports his two grandchildren who live with him. Adriano left Gaza for Maputo looking for a job. After getting there he stared working as a domestic worker and studying evenings. Today he is a retired teacher and has been making 3,034.56 meticais per month for more than 8 years. Besides earning his pension, he works as a gardener making 1,800 meticais per month. He also raises chicks owning a chicken coop where he raises on average 3 boxes. He spends 20,000 meticais making a profit of 1,800 meticais per month in case the weather is not too cold. He uses the money for household expenses and manages to put some money in his savings account. He has had a loan in the amount of 30,000 meticais with BIM, which is almost paid for. This is loan, in the amount of 15,000 meticais, is Adriano's first with Hluvuku and Kiva. He intends to buy chicks to raise and resell. He is confident that he will pay the loan back ahead of time. Based on this loan, he will assess if it is worth it to raise chicks with loans before requesting others.

Translated from Portuguese by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of chicks to raise and resell

loans.name: Rukhsana Bibi's Group

texts.en:
Rukhsana bibi lives in the city of Vehari in Pakistan with her family. Her husband works in a mill while her son is a hairdresser and runs a barber shop in the market. His father also helps him upon return from his own job. Rukhsana is a housewife. She manages the domestic chores, takes care of her family and prepares food for them. Her other three children are getting their education.

Rukhsana is applying for a loan from Asasah to assist her son, who wants to improve his barber shop by installing chairs and mirrors and buying hair color, creams and shampoos. She hopes that by making an investment in his business, his income will be increased and he will be able to have a better financial life.

loans.use: to purchase required items for the barber shop

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora D. is from the village of Bagong Silang, Iligan City. She is 38 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. Flora owns and operates a business raising livestock, primarily pigs, for sale. Flora has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Flora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Flora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Flora is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Flora from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

location.town: Bagong Silang, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Liv

texts.en:
There are many Cambodians who make a living as domestic cultivators; one of them is Mrs. Liv Y. who has been working in this sector since 1997. She grows rice and raises a few pigs on her own farmland that she inherited from her grandparents. She can generate an income of around US $3 per day from this business. She is a widowed mother who has four children: three are married and one is single.

For this rice-growing season, Liv Y. lacks some supplies to use on her farm field; however, she doesn’t yet have the money to purchase these items. Therefore, Liv Y. is applying for a Kiva loan to use towards buying fertilizer and seeds for planting.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seeds for planting

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon Q. is from the village of Napisik, Sulipat. She is 32 years old, married and has 1 school-aged child. Corazon owns and operates a quarrying business, primarily selling sand and gravel in the local community. Corazon has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns a monthly net income of 7,200 PHP. 

In 2004, Corazon joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Corazon has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC, which was used to invest in expanding the business. Corazon is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used use as start-up capital for food vending. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Corazon from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: start-up capital for a new business venture in food vending

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina has much faith and courage, which have helped her overcome the poverty that afflicts her family. She is 41 years old and married with three children, all of whom look to her for support. She lives in the town of Morong in the province of Rizal, Philippines.

In 2009, Josefina joined ASHI, a Kiva partner in the Philippines, in order to secure access to capital for her business raising hogs. This loan is her second, and she has repaid the previous loan on time and made good use of it to expand her business and her income. She has applied for a new loan of PHP 10,000 to buy sacks of feed and vitamins and to pay for transportation expenses. 

Josefina dreams of expanding her business into a full-fledged pig farm. She also dreams of sending her children to school until they finish college and find good jobs. Until that happens, she is pleased at the way in which ASHI and Kiva have changed her family's life and given them the possibility to make their dreams come true.

loans.use: To buy feed and vitamins and to pay for transportation expenses

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en: Nancy is a 31-year-old married woman. She has been supplying computers for two years and is also employed. She was previously a shop attendant. Nancy decided to go into business so as to supplement her family’s income. Being a member of Imani group in Faulu Kenya, she has been guaranteed a loan of 30,000 KES by the members. With this loan, she plans to increase her stock because she got a contract to supply computers.

loans.use: To increase her stock of computers

loans.name: Romulo

texts.en:
Romulo B. is from the village of Tabinar. He is 39 years old, married and has 5 school-aged children. Romulo owns and operates a general store, selling dry goods in the local community. Romulo has been engaged in his business for 7 years.

In 2009, Romulo joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Romulo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP, which was used as additional capital for his business. Romulo is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used for the expansion of the business. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Romulo from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his family's general living conditions.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Expansion of the business

loans.name: Doep

texts.en: Doep D. is 43 years old and married with five school-aged children. She is currently a recycling seller - she buys used goods to sell to a wholesaler, who then sells them in bulk to other countries. The used goods she buys and deals in are mostly leftover electrical wires and plastic. Her husband works as a requirement laborer, hired by people to carry their merchandise. Doep D. is looking for a loan to buy a new motorcycle in order to make her family transportation easier.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle.

loans.name: Almend

texts.en:
Almend C. is from the village of Guinabot. She is 36 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. Almend owns and operates a food market, selling foods and delicacies in the local community. Almend has been engaged in her business for 7 years and earns a monthly net income of 6,000 PHP.

In 2005, Almend joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Almend has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC, which was used as additional capital for the business. Almend is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used for the expansion of the business. This will be the 8th loan taken out by Almend from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Salvacion Babatid's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Salvacion B. is 57 years of age, married and a resident of Malaubang, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Salvacion B.’s Group.

Salvacion is married to Fausto B., a farmer and her business assistant. They were blessed with 2 children who are now adults with their own families. Five years ago, Salvacion decided to help her husband and became involved in the food-selling business, specializing in "puso", or hanging rice, and native vinegar. She has been able to maintain the business and now earns an average net monthly income of not less than 3,000 PHP, which is so helpful to their family income.

Upon hearing the good news of PAGLAUM MPC being one of the most outstanding cooperatives in Northern Mindanao and being awarded Most Outstanding Cooperative in the Philippines during the search for the COOP-LGU Partnership Award 2006, Salvacion joined the cooperative in 2009. As an active member of PAGLAUM MPC's PDP-LP Program, a microfinance program that reaches out to the rural poor, she is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP (her 3rd cycle loan) to be used for additional capital for her business. The future income from this loan will be used to improve her family's living conditions, to meet their basic needs, as loan repayments to PMPC and for possible business expansions.

loans.use: Additional capital for her business selling "puso" and vinegar

loans.name: Solidad

texts.en: Residing in the province of Rizal in the Philippines with her husband and three children, Solidad is 54 years-old, married, and the owner-operator of a rice retailing business in her neighborhood. A busy entrepreneur for almost 6 years, Solidad is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase additional rice. She believes in offering an inventory of rice in her house for customers seeking convenient purchases, and is grateful for access to capital and loans to fund her entrepreneurial dreams. Her long term goals are to expand her rice retail business and sustain her family financially.  With the support of Kiva lenders, she is focused on achieving additional business through her entrepreneurial efforts.

loans.use: To purchase an inventory of rice.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy, 45, has been a dairy farmer for 14 years.  As an active member of Step By Step group in Faulu Kenya, she saves her money on a weekly basis, investing those funds into her business.  The members of the group also guarantee one another's loans, so Lucy is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow.  By adding another cow, she will achieve more milk production and hopes to become a large-scale farmer in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Vann

texts.en: Mr. Vann S. is a low-income earner living in a rural area of Siem Reap, Cambodia. He operates his own business, buying and selling a variety of vegetables at the market. Additionally, Vann S. and his wife plant a few crops on their own farmland. They have four teenage children, all of whom are no longer in school and currently work at different jobs. In the past, not having his own vehicle, Vann S. always hired a neighbor’s motorcycle to pick up his vegetables to sell at the market. He now hopes to reduce this fee by asking for a loan to purchase a new motorbike. With any remaining cash from the loan, he will grow rice crops.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike

loans.name: Elma's Group

texts.en:
Elma A., from the village of Bagacay, is the 27-year-old group leader of a four-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each group member receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Elma, who is married and has three school-aged children, owns and operates a business selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Engaged in her business for over six years, she earns approximately 3,200 PHP a month.

In 2010, Elma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC, she is requesting a new loan of 5,000.00 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. Elma plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for the business

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en: Mary Jane is from the village of Guinabot. She is 33 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Mary Jane owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Mary Jane joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Mary Jane is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used for the expansion of her business. This loan will be her 2nd from PMPC. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. loans.name: Apolonia

texts.en:
Apolonia C., from the village of Bigaan, is 52 years old, married, and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Apolonia owns and operates a fish-selling business in the local community. Engaged in her business for over 10 years, she earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Apolonia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC that was used as additional capital for her business, she is now requesting a new loan, her 15th, for 10,000 PHP, to be used for house renovation.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy D. is from the village of Santa Cruz. She is 35 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Joy owns and operates a business selling cosmetics but her main source of income is her allotment of 20,000 PHP per month from her husband who is abroad. In 2006, Joy joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from PMPC. Joy is requesting a new loan of 35,000 PHP which will be used to purchase housing materials. This loan will be her 8th from PMPC. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase housing materials

loans.name: Enerika

texts.en: Enerika S. is currently in the business of selling local Sudanese food in her restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock ful beans (fava beans), a local Sudanese type of bean, to cook and sell. Enerika is 50 years old and is married to a retired soldier. She has seven children and four of her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her restaurant. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock ful beans, a local Sudanese type of bean, to cook and sell

loans.name: Norma

texts.en: Norma C. is from the village of Southwestern. She is 71 years old, is married, and has four adult children. Her primary source of income comes from her monthly pension of 7,100 PHP. In 2009, Norma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services and be able to obtain the different benefits offered by PMPC. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 26,000 PHP from PMPC. Norma is requesting a new loan of 55,000 PHP which will be used for her grandchild’s tuition fees. This loan will be her 4th from PMPC. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To pay her grandchild's tuition fees

loans.name: Pargev

texts.en:
Pargev K. lives in Sevan city with his parents, his wife and their one-year-old child. Pargev is 27 years old.

Since 2008, Pargev has been working in a gas-filling station as a working shift manager. And, since 2009, he has run a food shop and fast-food stand in the same gas-filling station. Also he does home delivery of fast food.

Pargev has taken a loan from Nor Horizon four times and now he is asking for a 1,000,000 AMD loan that he will use to buy a small trailer. He intends to carry his fast-food stand in that trailer.

loans.use: To buy a small trailer for his business

loans.name: Phoeurk

texts.en:
Mrs. Phoeurk S., a 33 year-old mother of a young child attending school, sells a little grocery inventory out of her home to help meet the needs of her family. She has been operating this business for four years and earns approximately $3.50 per day. To help support the family, her husband cultivates rice and vegetable crops.

Hoping to enlarge her business, Phoeurk S. is requesting a loan of $1000 to accumulate a larger number of grocery items to sell and to purchase some needed inputs for their farm field, measures that will allow her to increase her income and enable her family to attain a better standard of living.

loans.use: To accumulate a larger number of grocery items to sell.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn B. is from the village of Guinabot. She is 38 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Evelyn owns and operates a business selling vegetables in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month. In 2007, Evelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to buy copra (dried coconut meat used for oil production) to sell. This loan will be her 5th from PMPC. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her new copra business

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina joined ASHI, a Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 2009. When she received her previous loan, she invested the money in her food-vending business and later expanded the business with more foods.

Now on her 2nd loan, Gina requested 10,000 PHP as additional working capital for her business. She is positive that her business will grow since she already has regular customers requesting orders at home.

Gina dreams of having a permanent space in the marketplace where she can sell her ready-to-eat food to earn a much larger income. She hopes to have a successful business that can provide her with a good life that is moved out of poverty.

Gina is grateful to ASHI for offering her happiness in life and group support in achieving her goals.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her food-vending business

loans.name: Jein

texts.en: Jein L. is currently in the business of selling bags of maize, sorghum and millet at her store and is requesting a loan to stock bags of rice, beans and groundnuts (peanuts) to sell. Jein is 39 years old and is married to a peasant. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a car and extend the floor area of her store. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock bags of rice, beans and groundnuts to sell

loans.name: Chien

texts.en: Chien S., 52 years old, owns a small shop in front of her home where she sells food for her neighbors. She typically makes around $3 of profit each day to meet her family's needs. She has been married for many years to Peum Bo, 45, a palm climber, and they have four children: one is married and the other three are single. To help meet the family's expenses, two of the children are employed. Chien S. will be using this Kiva loan to purchase essential ingredients for cooking foods. She proposes to use the rest of the loan to buy an old motorcycle to make her family transportation easier.

loans.use: To purchase essential ingredients for cooking foods

loans.name: Sellen

texts.en:
Sellen I. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and fish at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock onions and some tomatoes to sell.  Sellen is 37 years old and married; her husband is a laborer. She has 3 children, who all attend school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to stock onions and some tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Loice

texts.en:
Loice K. is currently in the business of selling weaving materials at a beauty salon. She is requesting a loan to stock necklaces and earrings to sell.  Loice is 40 years old and married to a police officer. She has 6 children; only two go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to stock necklaces and earrings to sell

loans.name: Janarkul's Group

texts.en: Janarkul B. is the leader of this group. She is 49 and a widow. She has raised three sons and a daughter. The daughter is married and lives separately with her family, the two older sons went to work in Russia to earn some money, and the youngest son studies at school. In order to make money, Janarkul sells fruit and vegetables in the market. She started a year ago with an initial investment of 5,000 soms and now she makes 5,000 soms per month. She applied for a loan because she needs money to increase the turnover of her business and wants to start a wholesale trade. Nurbu A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 24 and married. Her husband works as a truck driver. He transports fruits and vegetables. A year ago, Nurbu and her husband decided to start selling fruits and vegetables on the market. They started with an initial investment of 5,000 soms and now they make 10,000 soms per month. With money received from this loan, Nurbu wants to increase the turnover of her business. In the future she plans to purchase a vehicle. Burulsun B., 47, is divorced. She has raised three sons and a daughter. The daughter is married and lives separately with her family. The two older sons work on construction and the youngest son studies at school. A year ago Nurbu decided to try to sell vegetables – she sold all her vegetables in one day and made good money. After that she started selling fruit and vegetables on the market. She applied for a loan because she needs money to increase her variety of fruits and vegetables. Dogdurbek D., 40, is married. Dogdurbek and his wife have been selling fruits and vegetables for ten years. They started with an initial investment of 5,000 soms and now they make 15,000 soms per month. The profit made it possible for them to purchase a house. With money received from the loan, Dogdurbek wants to increase the turnover of his business. In the future he plans to purchase a vehicle. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Roda

texts.en:
Roda B. is currently in the business of selling bread, groundnut products, and tomatoes. She is requesting a loan to stock onions and cooking oil to sell. Roda is 22 years old and is single. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a house for rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock onions and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Ameyo

texts.fr: A.  ameyo est une femme très dynamique, à 32 ans elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants, son époux est un conducteur de camion, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de détail de friperie, céréales et divers. Son stock a connu une baisse raison pour laquelle elle voudrait se réapprovisionner et  sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 1 balle de friperie, 5 sacs de céréales et divers.
texts.en:
Ameyo A. is a very dynamic woman. At 32, she is married and the mother of four children. Her husband is a truck driver. She earns money by selling second hand clothing, cereals, and various other products. Her supplies are low and she wants to restock. This is why she is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy one load of clothing, five sacks of cereal and various other items.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy clothing, cereals, and various items

loans.name: Joen

texts.en:
Joen D. is currently in the business of selling dried fish and tomatoes at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock Irish potatoes, cooking oil, and more tomatoes to sell. Joen is 34 years old and is married with a husband who is an inspector general. She has three children, all of whom go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a hotel.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock Irish potatoes, cooking oil, and more tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Loice

texts.en:
Loice K. is currently in the business of selling ice cream, bread, and fried fish at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock cooking oil to sell.  Loice is 29 years old and is married; her husband is an electrician. She has two children, one of whom goes to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Akossiwa

texts.fr: En 2000 cette femme s’est lancée dans le commerce de  produits d’alimentation générale, elle s’approvisionne dans les divers marchés locaux de Lomé, son stock actuel ne lui permet pas de satisfaire toute sa clientèle, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de  3 cartons de beurre, 6 cartons de sardine, 6 cartons de lait PEAK, 4 sacs de riz, 6 cartons de tomates et 6 cartons de savons BF. Elle a déjà obtenu chez WAGES un crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. Elle est Mariée et a une personne à sa charge
texts.en:
In 2000 this woman started a grocery business. She buys her stock in various neighborhood markets in Lome, but not in enough quantity to keep up with customer demand. She is asking WAGES for a loan to buy three packages of butter, six packages of sardines, six packages of Peak milk, four bags of rice, six packages of tomatoes and six of BF soaps. She has fully repaid one previous loan from WAGES. She is married and has one dependent.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy grocery products

loans.name: Nadou Celestine

texts.fr:
Celestine a 46 ans et exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de détail de tubercules d’ignames. Elle a 5 ans d’expérience dans ce commerce, pour réaliser une plus grande marge bénéficiaire sur ces ventes elle s’approvisionne à l’intérieur du pays dans la ville de Bassar. Sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes. La demande actuelle de sa clientèle est élevée c’est pour cela qu’elle sollicite de  WAGES un premier prêt pour acheter  6 lots d’ignames.
Elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants
texts.en:
Celestine is 46 years old; her line of business is retailing yams. She has five years of experience doing this; in order to obtain a greater profit margin, she stocks up in the interior part of the country, in the town of Bassar. She has a diverse customer base. The current customer demand is growing, which is why she is seeking her first loan from WAGES to purchase six yam lots. She is married and the mother of four children.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing yams [for resale]

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary J. is currently in the business of selling charcoal at home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Mary is 39 years old and is widowed. She has four children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. The programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Sodji

texts.fr: E. exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de produits d’alimentation générale, il fait  ce commerce depuis 5 ans  déjà et s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé, il souhaite gonfler son stock raison pour laquelle il sollicite de WAGES un crédit  pour s’approvisionner et augmenter son stock. Il est marié et a 2 personnes à sa charge.
texts.en:
To earn his living, E. has been selling groceries for five years. He buys his stock in the big market in Lome. He wants to build her stock, and that is why he is asking for a loan from WAGES. He is married with two dependents.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy grocery products

loans.name: Fernando Muroi

texts.pt:
Fernando Muroi G., nasceu na Provincia da Beira Capital Sofala Centro de Moçambique, é casado pai de 4 filhos de 5, 14 e 20 anos, todos vão a escola. Fez a 10ª classe não concluiu porque teve que ir a tropa. Vive na casa própria com sua familia e responsabiliza se pelas suas duas irmãs que vivem com ele.


Sai da Beira quando é recrutado, e durante 6 anos cumpriu serviço militar obrigatório, é desmobilizado e de seguida faz o curso de professorado. E funcionário permante com a categoria de Director da escola ha mais de 27 anos, auferindo 7.750.00mt mensal que aplica nas dispesas da casa. Inicia uma obra com o empréstimo que obteve no BIM, não concluida, aproxima se a Hluvuku solicitando empréstimo para dar continuidade da mesma. 



Este é o segundo empréstimo de Fernando na Hluvuku e primeiro com Kiva no valor de 20.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, ferro, areia e chapas de zinco) para dar continuidade da sua obra. O anterior no valor de 10.000.00mt foi usado para a mesma finalidade.

 Esta  confiante que vai pagar antes do tempo previsto e pedir um novo empréstimo para construção de uma cerámica.
texts.en:
Fernando Muroi was born in the Province Beira Capital Sofala, in central Mozambique. He is married and father to 4 children who are 5, 14 and 20 years old. All children go to school. He studied until the 10th grade but didn't finish school because he was drafted. He lives in his own home with his family and also supports two sisters who live with him. He left Beira when he was drafted and was in mandatory military service during 6 years. After leaving the service he took teacher's training. He has had a permanent job with Principal's level for more than 27 years. He makes 7,750 meticais per month, which is used for household expenses. He has started construction with a loan obtained from BIM. He has not finished construction and now comes to Hluvuku to request a loan to continue it. This is Fernando's second loan with Hluvuku and first with Kiva, in the amount of 20,000 meticais. He intends to purchase construction materials (cement, iron, sand and zinc sheets) to continue construction. His previous loan, in the amount of 10,000 meticais, was used for the same goal. He is confident he will pay the loan back ahead of schedule and request another loan to build a pottery/brick factory.

Translated from Portuguese by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials (cement, iron, sand and zinc sheets)

loans.name: Akossiwavi

texts.fr: S.  est une femme âgée de 35 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants, en 2007 elle s’est lancée dans le commerce de produits d’alimentation générale, sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes. Son stock de marchandises a baissé ce qui a entrainé une baisse de ses recettes, elle voudrait  rehausser son stock pour accroître ses recettes. Elle sollicite alors de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 2 sacs de riz, 3 cartons de sucre, 2 cartons de savons, 1 cartons de biscuits, 1 cartons de spaghetti et du charbon de bois
texts.en:
S. is 35, married, and has three children. In 2007 she got into the grocery business. Her customers are drawn from all backgrounds. Since her stock is low, she has suffered a drop in income. She wants to build her stock so as to increase her income. With a WAGES loan she plans to buy two sacks of rice, three packages of sugar, two packages of soap, one package of cookies and one of spaghetti, plus charcoal.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy grocery products

loans.name: Awoussi

texts.fr:
Après son apprentissage en coiffure, T. a ouvert son salon de coiffure qu’elle a appelé «  GRACE DIVINE », elle a associé à cela la vente de  produits cosmétiques. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé, sa clientèle se compose essentiellement de femme.  Elle souhaite s’approvisionner en produits cosmétiques raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter des tissages, des mèches, des produits défrisants et divers.
Elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants. Elle vit avec  sa famille dans le quartier d’agoè  anomé
texts.en:
After an apprenticeship T. opened her own beauty salon, which she calls "Divine Grace." She also sells cosmetics. She buys her stock in the big market in Lome. Her customers are women. She is asking for a loan from WAGES to buy braids, extensions, straightening products and other goods. She is married and has four children, and lives with her family in the Agoè Anomé neighborhood.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy braids, extensions, straightening products and other cosmetics

loans.name: Lubov's Group

texts.en: Lubov P. is the leader of this group. She is 52 and married. She has two daughters, both of whom are married and live separately with their families. Lubov and her husband provide car repair services and have been doing this for seventeen years. In this way they make 8,000 soms per month. With the money received from the loan, Lubov wants to purchase a fridge to improve her living conditions. Svetlana R., 32, is married. She has two sons and a daughter: the older son is eight and studies at school and the others are too young. Svetlana and her husband began to provide car repair services three years ago and in this way they make 8,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan Svetlana wants to purchase an oven in order to improve her living conditions. In the future she plans to purchase cattle for breeding. Ekaterina O., 25, is married. She works as a cook and her husband is a programmer in a bank. Ekaterina applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase a personal computer. Margarita S., 40, is married. Eight years ago, she and her husband began to sell household goods. They started with an initial investment of 1,000 soms and now they make 2,800 soms per month. Margarita wants to start providing sewing services, so she applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase a sewing machine. Nataliya A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 40 and married with three sons and three daughters. Two sons and the daughter are married and live separately with their families while the other children study at school. Ten years ago, with an initial investment of 4,000 soms, Nataliya purchased a calf and started to breed cattle. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase a bull in order to resell it at a higher price after fattening. In the future she plans to open a sewing workshop. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase a fridge

loans.name: Yousef

texts.en:
Yousef is a 37-year-old man from Tulkarem. He is the father of five children who are school students. Yousef is an employee with a very small salary that is barely enough to cover his household expenses.

Yousef came to FATEN to take a $550 loan to cover dental expenses, because his income is too low to pay for a dental insurance plan, and he is suffering from dental problems. Because his dental treatment was expensive, he had to take a loan to pay for it.

In the picture, Yousef appears FATEN's office in Tulkarem.

loans.use: Dental treatment

loans.name: Amézima

texts.fr: Cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de pagnes, bijoux, elle fait ce commerce depuis 2008 et s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé. Pour conquérir une plus grande clientèle elle fait son commerce de façon ambulante. Sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes, elle voudrait gonfler son stock raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de  pagnes de diverses qualités et des bijoux. Etant célibataire, c’est avec le revenu de son commerce qu’elle subvient aux charges de son époux.
texts.en:
This woman has been earning her living by selling tradtional cloth and jewelry since 2008. She buys her stock in the big market in Lome. To reach more customers, she sells door-to-door. Her customers are from all backgrounds. To build her stock, she is asking for a loan from WAGES to buy traditional cloth of various qualities and jewelry. As a single woman she needs the income from her business to make up for not being supported by a husband.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy traditional cloth

loans.name: Afi

texts.fr: Cette dame est une femme mariée et mère de 3 enfants, elle vit avec sa famille dans le quartier de agoé fiovi, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de charbon de bois, une partie de son stock a été détruite par les pluies de ces derniers jours, elle voudrait se réapprovisionner raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 20 sacs de charbons de bois.
texts.en:
This lady is a married woman and the mother of three children. She lives with her family in the Agoé Fiovi district. She has a revenue-generating business involving charcoal. Part of her stock has been destroyed by the rains of recent days. She would like to stock up again. For this reason, she is requesting a loan from WAGES for buying 20 sacks of charcoal.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying charcoal

loans.name: Nurlan

texts.en:
K. Nurlan Manapovich was born in Orlovka village (Kemin region) where he still lives at the moment. He’s 37 years old. After graduating from school he went into the army. After this, he married Kanaeva Raihan, with whom he has four children: three daughters of school age and a little son who is only one and a half years old. Nurlan works as a security guard in the Altynken goldmine. Nurlan’s spouse is a housewife.

Since Nurlan is the only breadwinner in a large family, being a hard-working, responsible and enterprising man, he decided to open up a small shop in his garage three years ago. The garage was refurbished into a shop within one week. With a part of his salary of 3,000 Kyrgyz Soms, Nurlan bought groceries. The range of products in his corner shop was not sufficient, and after thinking for a while and considering all the risks, Nurlan got his first loan from Bai Tushum & Partners. Thus, he could widen the range of products and his shop, which he runs with his wife and older children (in their spare time), allows them to earn some extra money. The shop is open 24/7 and Nurlan has his permanent customers, to whom he gives some discounts and, in case of need, lends goods.

About one month ago, Nurlan’s shop was robbed. More than half of the goods (with a value of 50,000 Kyrgyz Soms) and the sale proceeds of a whole day were stolen. It was a big loss for Nurlan, but he quickly gathered his courage again. In view of the importance of the additional revenue from the shop for his family, Nurlan wants to obtain a loan of 40,000 Kyrgyz Soms to restock his shop with products.

The most important thing for Nurlan is his family; he wants to provide his children with a good education. This in turn will allow them help advance their country and their people.

loans.use: to purchase groceries

loans.name: Amatou

texts.fr: Cette femme est veuve, pour subvenir à ses besoins elle s’est lancée dans le commerce de sacs de charbons de bois, comptant sur son expérience en commerce elle a associé à ce commerce plus tard la vente de produits d’alimentation.
